document.docAuthor: Ivanov, Kaloyan, Hightower, Liberty, Dash, Shawn T. & Keiper, Joe B.
document.masterDocTitle: 150 years in the making: first comprehensive list of the ants (Hymenoptera: Formicidae) of Virginia, USA

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: 150 years in the making: first comprehensive list of the ants (Hymenoptera: Formicidae) of Virginia, USA

subSubSection.paragraph:
argentea Wheeler. Shenandoah
(MMPC). Literature records: “
Virginia
” ( Francoeur 1973 , 1974 ,
Peck et al. 1998
,
Guenard et al. 2012
).

The only reliable Virginia record of
F. argentea
is that of Francoeur (1974; p. 261) which is based on examination of materials in Forel’s collection ( 1 worker and 1 male , “ 4-VII-1880 , T. Pergande”). Records in
Peck et al. (1998)
and MMPC are likely based on misidentifications of the locally common
Formica subsericea
. More interesting is the record in Francoeur (1973; p. 150) which is based on examination of specimens (no county and locality data) at the Department of Entomology, University of Minnesota , Saint Paul. It is possible that the specimen label “ Virginia ” refers to the town of Virginia in northern Minnesota where
argentea
is not uncommon. Virginia records reported in
Guenard et al. (2012)
are based on Francoeur (1974) and
Peck et al. (1998)
.

subaenescens Emery. James City
(FMNH). Literature records: “ Whitetop Mtn .” (
Van Pelt 1963
), “
Virginia
” ( Francoeur 1974 ,
Guenard et al. 2012
).

All Virginia records of this species appear under the name
Formica fusca Linnaeus. As
currently understood true
fusca
is restricted to the Palearctic region and does not occur in North America. The Virginia record of
F. subaenescens in Francoeur (1974; p. 262)
is based on examination of materials in Forel’s collection ( 2 workers , “T. Pergande”). Van Pelt’s record from Whitetop Mtn. may also refer to
F. subaenescens
but we have not had a chance to examine his specimens. The record reported in
Guenard et al. (2012)
is based on Francoeur (1974) . James City Co. is located in Virginia’s Coastal Plain and as such, the FMNH record from this locality is most likely a misidentification of
F. subsericea
.
Formica subaenescens
is a northern species, which should occur in high altitude sites in the western part of the state.
